claim: Electronics have become more affordable in the US since 1990.

supporting.text: The average price of consumer electronics such as televisions, computers, and smartphones has decreased significantly since 1990 due to advancements in manufacturing and economies of scale.

attacks.text: The average price of consumer electronics such as televisions, computers, and smartphones has decreased significantly since 1990 due to advancements in manufacturing and economies of scale.
While average prices have decreased, the cost of high-end electronics (e.g., flagship smartphones, premium TVs) has risen, skewing affordability for many consumers.
High-end electronics represent a small fraction of the market, and their price increases are offset by much larger affordability gains in mid-range and budget devices.
Inflation-adjusted prices may not reflect true affordability, as wage stagnation in the US since 1990 means electronics consume a larger share of disposable income for many households.

Productivity gains in electronics manufacturing outpace wage stagnation, making today's devices far more capable per dollar than 1990 equivalents (e.g., smartphones replacing multiple standalone devices).
Hidden costs like required subscriptions (streaming services, cloud storage) and shorter product lifespans offset apparent price reductions.
Subscription models provide ongoing value (updates, content) unavailable in 1990, while planned obsolescence claims are overstated given modern devices' software-upgradable nature.

supporting.text: Inflation-adjusted data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics shows that the cost of electronics has declined relative to other consumer goods since 1990.

attacks.text: Inflation-adjusted data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics shows that the cost of electronics has declined relative to other consumer goods since 1990.
The Bureau of Labor Statistics data does not account for the rapid obsolescence of electronics, which forces consumers to replace devices more frequently, increasing overall expenditure.
Even with frequent replacements, the per-unit cost of electronics has dropped so significantly that total spending remains lower when adjusted for inflation and technological advancement.
The data aggregates all electronics, masking price increases in high-demand categories like smartphones and laptops, which have seen rising average selling prices.
While some high-end electronics have increased in price, budget and mid-range options have expanded, making affordable alternatives widely available.

supporting.text: Technological advancements and increased competition in the electronics industry have driven prices down, making devices more affordable for consumers.

attacks.text: Technological advancements and increased competition in the electronics industry have driven prices down, making devices more affordable for consumers.
While prices have dropped for some electronics, inflation-adjusted wages have stagnated, reducing actual affordability for many consumers.
Product lifespans have decreased significantly, forcing consumers to replace devices more frequently and increasing long-term costs.
High-end electronics (e.g., flagship smartphones) have seen price increases, creating affordability gaps between basic and premium devices.
The used/refurbished electronics market has expanded dramatically, providing affordable alternatives to new devices.

supporting.text: The introduction of global supply chains and outsourcing production to lower-cost regions has reduced the price of electronics in the US market since 1990.

attacks.text: The introduction of global supply chains and outsourcing production to lower-cost regions has reduced the price of electronics in the US market since 1990.
While outsourcing reduces production costs, rising tariffs and trade wars since 2016 have increased the final prices of electronics in the US.
Tariffs affect only a subset of electronics, and many manufacturers absorb cost increases rather than passing them to consumers.
Inflation-adjusted prices for high-end electronics (e.g., flagship smartphones) have actually increased due to premium features and branding.
Budget and mid-range electronics have seen significant price drops, offsetting premium segment increases for most consumers.

supporting.text: The Consumer Price Index (CPI) for electronic goods indicates a consistent downward trend in prices since 1990, reflecting increased affordability.

attacks.text: The Consumer Price Index (CPI) for electronic goods indicates a consistent downward trend in prices since 1990, reflecting increased affordability.
The CPI does not account for quality improvements, which may mean consumers are paying more for better-performing electronics rather than the same products becoming cheaper.
Hedonic quality adjustments are applied to CPI calculations to account for improvements in product quality, ensuring price trends reflect true affordability.
The CPI basket may not fully represent actual consumer spending, as it updates infrequently and may miss rapid shifts in electronic goods consumption.
The Bureau of Labor Statistics periodically updates the CPI basket to reflect current consumer preferences, including frequent updates for technology categories.

supporting.text: The proliferation of budget-friendly electronics brands and models has expanded access to affordable technology for US consumers since 1990.

attacks.text: The proliferation of budget-friendly electronics brands and models has expanded access to affordable technology for US consumers since 1990.
While budget brands exist, inflation-adjusted prices for high-end electronics (e.g., flagship smartphones, GPUs) have risen significantly since 1990.
High-end electronics represent a small fraction of the market, and the average price of mainstream electronics (e.g., TVs, laptops) has consistently declined.
Many budget electronics have shorter lifespans or lower quality, forcing consumers to replace them more frequently and increasing long-term costs.
Even with shorter lifespans, the total cost of ownership for budget electronics remains lower than premium alternatives from the 1990s when adjusted for inflation.
The affordability claim ignores hidden costs like mandatory subscriptions, accessories, or planned obsolescence that inflate true expenses.
